awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Quantifying Structural Loading from Tsunami-Induced Debris Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Tsunamis and storm surges pose a significant threat to coastal communities around the world.  In tsunami risk zones, the threats from large-scale coastal inundation are exacerbated by the accumulation of large debris fields that impact and build up around critical infrastructure systems.  These debris fields are composed of various objects that move with the incoming flow and that range in size from construction materials from damaged buildings to vehicles and large watercraft.  To lessen the risks and damage to coastal infrastructure and ultimately improve the welfare of communities in these risk zones, improved design and strategic retrofit strategies are necessary and require a better understanding of the forces associated with such debris impacts, specifically forces associated with large, disorganized debris fields.  Previous studies have addressed the effect of wave and flow loads on infrastructure, but few have examined the influence of multiple pieces of debris, or debris fields carried by such flows.  Flow driven debris fields are fundamentally chaotic in nature; nearly identical initial conditions can lead to widely varying outcomes.  Thus, predicting the loads arising from these events requires a statistical approach to help address the uncertainties with how debris interacts with and affects the built environment.  Using a combination of experimental results and numerical modeling, this project will quantify the impact forces and damming effects in a manner valid for this kind of highly nonlinear, chaotic system.  The results of this research will provide key information to enable improved safety and sustainability of structural systems in coastal regions and to improve post-event response and recovery efforts.  Data from this project will be archived in the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Data Depot (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org).  This project contributes to NSF's role in the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program.  

This project will combine two distinct experimental programs, one at the NHERI large wave flume facility at Oregon State University and the other at the University of Washington, with a strategic numerical modeling approach to predict debris-induced forces on structures in tsunami hazard zones.  The large number of potential debris impact scenarios, combined with the disparate nature of debris fields across coastal communities impacted by large wave events, is well beyond the practical scope of any single experimental program.  Thus, the development of a robust, predictive numerical approach is critical to improving the understanding of complex debris-fluid-structure interaction phenomena.  This research has three primary objectives: (1) generate statistically representative experimental test results for flow-driven, multi-debris impact scenarios to inform numerical modeling efforts; (2) develop, refine, and combine a series of complex numerical models capable of capturing the key physical phenomena associated with the experimental results; and (3) extend the numerical models using a statistics-based approach to debris-induced force predictions under broader scenarios.  By using a statistical approach, this research will develop a physically meaningful, representative numerical estimate of the risks of debris impact and damming forces, supported by experimental results that will provide engineers and community officials with an improved confidence for designing safe and resilient coastal infrastructure in tsunami and storm surge susceptible regions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Among the least understood phenomena associated with large wave events such as tsunamis or storm surge wave is the impact of debris interacting the built environment.  This project was awarded to address the challenge of predicting loads created by flow-driven collections of debris impacting structures, with a focus on quantifying impact forces and damming effects in a manner valid for this kind of highly nonlinear, chaotic system. The combined experimental-numerical study had three primary objectives: (1) generate statistically representative experimental test results for flow-driven, multi-debris impact scenarios; (2) develop complex numerical models capable of capturing the key physical phenomena associated with the experimental results; (3) extend the models using a statistics-based approach to debris-induced force predictions under broader scenarios. 

Beginning in March 2021 at the NHERI Large Wave Flume, we completed over 400 individual trials of disparate debris fields impacting a test specimen that represents a typical coastal structure.  Variations in the test setup included debris configuration, number of pieces of debris, and flow characteristics.  Throughout these trials, we were able to collect flow data (e.g., wave heights, flow velocities), impact and damming response data (e.g., pressures, streamwise forces), data related to interactions within the debris field (e.g., accelerometer data on individual pieces of debris, video recordings of the impacts), and structural dynamics data for the test specimen. 

Experimental data was used to inform two distinct numerical modeling frameworks to address different aspects of the debris-fluid-structure interaction problem.  First, an open source solver FOAMySees was developed to facilitate simulation of fluid-structure interactions between standard computational fluid dynamics models and finite element analysis.  The model was developed in the popular computational fluid dynamics toolbox OpenFOAM and the nonlinear structural solver OpenSees, respectively, to provide a fully open source framework that is freely available to the research and engineering community.  By combining the two approaches, we allow for the evaluation of nonlinear structural response to multi-hazard excitation to assist in the investigation of site-specific resilience of structures subject to cascading or multi-hazards through numerical analysis methods.

In parallel, a numerical framework for modeling tsunamis driving groups of debris, or debris fields, was also developed using the material point method (MPM) combined with an FEA approach into an augmented MPM-FEA framwork that retains the strength of both methods, specifically large deformation fluid problems (MPM) and simulation of solids (FEA).  This approach was adapted to a Multi-GPU (graphical processing unit) system typically used for video games and machine learning, which we call ClaymoreUW.  This has accelerated simulations by 10-100x and enabled the development of a series of digital twins of various flume facilities around the world.  Prioritizing flexibility, speed, and simplicity has led us to the most basic algorithm for debris-fluid-structure interaction identified yet, which we have shown to be a novel solution.  The speed with which we are able to achieve results has enabled brute force approaches to preliminary stochastic analyse.

As we continue to improve our understanding of how natural hazards impact our communities, engineers are looking for more tools to better understand the complex interactions that occur during these events.  Through collaboration with the NHERI SimCenter, the modeling approaches have been deployed in the HydroUQ application for public use.  These tools will allow engineers to build simulations of experiments within NHERI facilities and determine forces imparted to specific structural components when structures are subject to wave impact and other natural hazards. 

The success of our modeling efforts related to large deformations, fluid-structure interactions, and large-scale debris field impacts using the FoamySees and ClaymoreUW approaches are broadly applicable to large scale fluid-structure interaction problems and flow-induced impact phenomena.  More and more modelers are developing multiphysics approaches to solve mutihazard problems, and the generalized debris-fluid-soil-structure interactions that this work has enabled are key to progressing in this area.  It is reasonable to expect these results could be used in topics related to marine and ocean engineering, granular flows, or impact mechanics, among others. 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Michael Motley

por.por_txt_cntn:
Among the least understood phenomena associated with large wave events such as tsunamis or storm surge wave is the impact of debris interacting the built environment. This project was awarded to address the challenge of predicting loads created by flow-driven collections of debris impacting structures, with a focus on quantifying impact forces and damming effects in a manner valid for this kind of highly nonlinear, chaotic system. The combined experimental-numerical study had three primary objectives: (1) generate statistically representative experimental test results for flow-driven, multi-debris impact scenarios; (2) develop complex numerical models capable of capturing the key physical phenomena associated with the experimental results; (3) extend the models using a statistics-based approach to debris-induced force predictions under broader scenarios.
Beginning in March 2021 at the NHERI Large Wave Flume, we completed over 400 individual trials of disparate debris fields impacting a test specimen that represents a typical coastal structure. Variations in the test setup included debris configuration, number of pieces of debris, and flow characteristics. In parallel, a numerical framework for modeling tsunamis driving groups of debris, or debris fields, was also developed using the material point method (MPM) combined with an FEA approach into an augmented MPM-FEA framwork that retains the strength of both methods, specifically large deformation fluid problems (MPM) and simulation of solids (FEA). More and more modelers are developing multiphysics approaches to solve mutihazard problems, and the generalized debris-fluid-soil-structure interactions that this work has enabled are key to progressing in this area. It is reasonable to expect these results could be used in topics related to marine and ocean engineering, granular flows, or impact mechanics, among others.
